titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Ignace Jan Paderewski papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Linda Bernard

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-08-03T15:59-0700

change.item: Revised to add links to digital collections site by Sarah Patton.
Revised to add incremental motion picture film by Elizabeth Phillips.
Revised to update encoding, extent statement, and add unitid by Samira Bozorgi.
Revised to update encoding and add unitid by Elizabeth Phillips.
PUBLIC "-//Stanford University::Hoover Institution Archives//TEXT (US::CSt-H::::Ignacy Jan Paderewski papers)//EN" "paderew.sgm" converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.cdl.xsl (2004-09-16).

physdesc.extent: 10 manuscript boxes, 1 oversize box, 1 album box, 2 envelopes, 1 motion picture film reel, memorabilia

did.abstract: Correspondence, speeches and writings, clippings, printed matter, and photographs relating primarily to the establishment of an independent Polish state, the Paris Peace Conference, Polish politics in the interwar period, the occupation of Poland during World War II, and the musical career of I. J. Paderewski. Digital copies of select records also available at https://digitalcollections.hoover.org.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Use copy of the motion picture film in this collection is available for immediate access; digital copy also available at https://digitalcollections.hoover.org.

userestrict.head: Restrictions
userestrict.p: Must be served one folder at a time.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item] Igancy Jan Paderewski papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1975.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

altformavail.head: Alternate Forms Available
altformavail.p: Digital copies of select records also available at https://digitalcollections.hoover.org.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Ignace Jan Paderewski (also known as Ignacy Jan Paderewski) was a Polish statesman and musician.

chronitem.event: Born, Kurylowka, Podolia, Ukraine
Studied music, Warsaw Conservatory
Taught piano, Warsaw Conservatory
Married Antonina Korsak, who died a year later
Studied in Berlin under Friedrich Kiel
Studied in Vienna under Theodor Leschetizky Taught at Strasbourg Conservatory
Made first public appearances as a pianist in Vienna, Paris, London, and New York
Composed "The Polish Fantasia" for piano and orchestra (Opus 19)
Established the Paderewski Fund in support of musical compositions in the United States
Settled in Riond-Bosson near Morges, Switzerland
Married Helena Gorska
Composed the opera Manru
Director, Warsaw Conservatory
Presented the City of Krakow with a monument commemorating the victory of the Poles over the Teutonic Order upon the 500th anniversary of the Battle of Grunwald
Member and representative to the United States, General Committee for Polish Relief (organized in Switzerland in January)
Member and representative to the United States, Polish National Committee; frequently urged Woodrow Wilson to include Poland in his Fourteen Points

eventgrp.event: Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of Poland; delegate, Paris Peace Conference
Resigned November 27 and returned to Riond-Bosson

chronitem.event: Delegate plenipotentiary of Poland to the League of Nations
Resumed musical career in Europe and the United States
Author (with Mary Lawton), The Paderewski Memoirs
President, Polish National Council (Rada Narodowa) of the Polish Government-in-Exile, Paris
Left Europe for the United States
Died, New York City

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, speeches and writings, clippings, printed matter, and photographs relating primarily to the establishment of an independent Polish state, the Paris Peace Conference, Polish politics in the interwar period, the occupation of Poland during World War II, and the musical career of I. J. Paderewski.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Affidavit, certificates, correspondence, eulogies, financial papers, lists, will, and clippings and other printed matter, arranged alphabetically by physical form.

did.unittitle: Affidavit re attack of Jewish organizations and defamatory fliers,
Announcement for the inauguration of a bronze statue by Milo Martin to the memory of Paderewski, Morges, Switzerland,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Affidavits, bank statements, bills, correspondence, income assessments, income tax returns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes notes, table arrangements.

did.unittitle: Audience with Pope Pius XI. Notice and clipping,
Birthday, 80th. Acknowledgments for birthday greetings, and tribute by Gustave Doret (in French)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes letters relating to other musicians or music in general, including Ernest Schelling.

did.unittitle: Incoming, including Alfred Cortot, William S. Hawk, Vladimir Horowitz
Outgoing [See also: CORRESPONDENCE/Engles, Musaceous, Musikurs, Schelling, Steinway, Urchs]
Strakacz, Sylwin. Biography prepared for the Polish press
Paris Peace Conference, 1919. Letter of resignation as delegate to the Paris Peace Conference, addressed to Jozef Pilsudski,
League of Nations, 1920. Telegrams of acceptance and of resignation, addressed to Prince Sapieha,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mainly correspondence with or about.

did.unittitle: Gorski, Waclaw (son of Helena Paderewska by first marriage),
Paderewska, Maria (sister). Paderewski's telegram on her behalf to Maxim Litvinov,
Paderewski, Jan (father). Document signed by Jan Paderewski (in Russian),

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes legal documents.

did.unittitle: Honorary degrees [See: CORRESPONDENCE, Columbia University and Harvard University]
Name Day. Congratulatory message signed by Polish soldiers interned in Switzerland,
Departure from Switzerland and travel through France and Spain en route to the United States (September). Correspondence and clippings, including re arrival in the United States (November 6),

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Holograph and photostat positive copy of entire document and related papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters, notes, and telegrams, arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent. Includes some correspondence of Helena Paderewska, and some in the hand of Paderewski's secretary, Sylwin Strakacz.

did.unittitle: Drafts of letters and telegrams addressed to different people on the same sheet,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondents include Bishop Adamski, King Albert of Belgium, Mrs. Szymon Askenazy, Albert Blondel, Adolphe Boschot, Raoul Choussaud, Jan Ciechanowski, Marja Cielewiczowa, Count Clauzel, P. Czescik, Jozef Dowboz Musnicki, Mrs. Drohinska, Hamilton Fish, Waclaw Gorski, Princess Gortschakoff, Adam Grzymala-Siedlecki, Henri Guisan, Joseph Haller, August Hlond, J. Horodyski, Count Jancoyski, S. W. Jarakomski, Tadeusz Jentys, Reverend Kasaczun, Jan Koch, Mrs. Krajewska, Stanislaw Kruczek, Mary Lawton, Maxime Leroy, Irene Loevenberg, Mr. Martinet, Stanislaw Milaszewski, J. Modzelewski, Andrzej Moszczynski, Jozef K. Orlowski, Jozefowa Pilsudska, Andre Poniatowski, Wladyslaw Raczkiewicz, Jan Romaszkiewicz, Theodore and Mrs. Roosevelt, Wladyslaw Sikorski, Colonel Smigielski, Jan F. Smulski, Mr. Sobinski, Wladyslaw Sobanski, Marquise de St. Paul, Stefan Starzynski, Maurice Sternberger, Mrs. Venizelos, Mr. Wielowieyski, Woodrow and Mrs. Wilson, and August Zaleski.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a letter to a Norwegian journalist, 1924?

did.unittitle: Albert I, King of the Belgians, and Queen Elisabeth,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes letter from Court Marshall regarding the Queen's intercession with Berlin to facilitate Prince Ladislas Radziwill's departure from German-occupied Poland.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence regarding the financing of the newspaper. Includes a letter from Wydzial Narodowy Polski w Ameryce.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with Edwin B. Orcutt.

scopecontent.p: Dedications, essays, messages, notes, open letters, speeches, tributes, and writings, arranged chronologically by title.

scopecontent.p: Including with Francis X. Swietlik, 1940-1941; letter from Maurice Pate to Swietlik, 1941; and diplomatic correspondence, 1941 (in Polish).

United States - Foreign relations - Poland. Radiogram from Robert Lansing to Paderewski communicating de iure recognition of Poland by the United States; and holograph letter from Paderewski to Lansing,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bulletins, clippings, newsletters, pamphlets, serial issues, and miscellany relating mainly to Paderewski and to Poland, particularly before and during World War II. In English, Polish, French, and Portuguese.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Charcoal drawing of Paderewski's head and shoulders by W. T. Benda.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bust of Paderewski, and paperweight with his head in relief.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 126 prints and 6 postcards depicting Paderewski and others, atrocities committed in Poland during World War II, Polish children and soldiers, and miscellany.

did.unittitle: One album containing 83 prints and 4 postcards,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Depicts Paderewski at various events and others, including Mr. and Mrs. Bagniewski, Jan Ciechanowski, King George VI, Mr. and Mrs. Gutowski, Monsignor Kaczynski, I. Kollupajlo-La Grange, Tommy Majewski, Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Lily Pons, Wladyslaw Raczkiewicz, Eleanor Roosevelt, Wladyslaw Sikorski, Minister Stanczyk, Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, Aniela Strakacz, Sylwin Strakacz, Tadeusz Styka, Francis X. Swietlik, A. Syski, Antonina Wilkonska, Mr. and Mrs. Witkowski, and Adam Zamoyski, and scenes from his funeral at Arlington Cemetery, 1941 July 6. Includes prints depicting busts of Paderewski by Malvina Hoffman and N. Tregor.

did.unittitle: 1 print depicting a portrait of Paderewski by Tadeusz Styka, 1939; 1 print depicting Paderewski with Wladyslaw Sikorski, 1941; 1 print and 2 postcards depicting lodgings of Polish soldiers interned in Switzerland during World War II, with Paderewski's portrait hung on the walls; and 2 miscellany prints, undated

30 prints depicting atrocities committed in Poland during World War II; 6 prints depicting Polish children being fed by the Commission for Polish Relief, Winter 1940-1941; 2 prints depicting Polish soldiers, including one being decorated by General Sikorski with the Virtuti Militari order, undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The 35mm motion picture film contains several attempts at an interview with Paderewski, the Polish pianist, by MieczysÅaw Marchlewski, Poland's Consul General in New York, likely taking place in the Polish Consulate General at 233 Madison Avenue. The interview promotes Paderewski's appearance at the benefit for unemployed musicians in 1932. The concert was held on February 8, 1932 in Madison Square Garden in New York, so the date of the interview is probably late January or very early February 1932.

dao.title: Motion picture film, Ignace Paderewski interview
